context: Near Tamins-Reichenau the Anterior Rhine and the Posterior Rhine join and form the Rhine. The river makes a distinctive turn to the <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4>north<a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> near <a5_0><a5_1><a5_2><a5_3><b10_0>Chur<b10_0/><a5_3/><a5_2/><a5_1/><a5_0/>. This section is nearly <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4><a6_0><a6_1><a6_2><a6_3><a6_4><b11_0><b13_0>86 km<b13_0/><b11_0/><a6_4/><a6_3/><a6_1/><a6_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_1/> long<a6_2/><a1_2/>,<a1_0/> and descends from a height of <a7_0><a7_1><a7_2><a7_3><a7_4><b14_0>599 m<b14_0/><a7_4/><a7_3/><a7_0/> to 396 m<a7_2/><a7_1/>. It flows through a wide glacial alpine valley known as the <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4><a8_0><a8_1><a8_2><a8_3><a8_4>Rhine Valley<a8_4/><a8_3/><a8_2/><a8_1/><a8_0/><a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> (German: Rheintal). <a3_1>Near <a3_0><a3_2><a3_3><a3_4><b12_0>Sargans<b12_0/><a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> a natural dam, only a few metres high, prevents it from flowing into the open Seeztal valley and then through Lake Walen and Lake Zurich into the river Aare. The Alpine Rhine begins in the most western part of the Swiss canton of Graubünden, and later forms the border between <a9_0><a9_1><a9_3><a9_4>Switzerland<a9_4/><a9_3/><a9_1/><a9_0/> to the West and <a4_1><a9_2>Liechtenstein<a9_2/><a4_1/> and later <a4_0><a4_2><a4_3><a4_4>Austria<a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_0/> to the East.
